messages: f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (02:16): hsivonen, I'm curious why validator.nu would report that 'type' and 'data' attributes are not allowed on 'object' when the spec certainly appears to allow them, e.g. see: http://validator.nu/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Ftantek.com%2F&parser=html5&profile=polyglot
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (02:16): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/the-iframe-element.html#attr-object-type
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:17): probably a bug in the validator, file a bug :-)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (02:18): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I tend to assume it's a bug in my code before thinking it's a bug in the validator :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:18): looks like a validator bug to me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): yeah

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): it fails on data:text/html;charset=utf-8,<!DOCTYPE%20HTML><title>Test</title><object%20type%3D"image/png"%20data%3D"http://example.com/test.png"></object> too
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:20): which i'm pretty sure is valid
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (02:30): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e - bug filed: http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=716 (noted link to your test case also)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: cool
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:35): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: hey while i have you here, do you have an opinion on getting rid of the "magic" around N in the microdata vCard vocabulary?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:36): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: i was looking at the vCard spec and it doesn't say the N needs to actually have any data, just that it has to be present

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (02:42): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: In fact, "normal internet users"  have to be pretty careful about how they use H.264. See http://bemasc.net/wordpress/2010/02/02/no-you-cant-do-that-with-h264/ ... that's mostly about video production, but it also turns out that e.g. playing video using Flash for "commercial use" is also forbidden
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:43): man i hate working on the drag-and-drop API

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:57): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: They have to be careful they pay for a service that doesn't properly license its content, and even then nothing's going to happen
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (02:59): Internet broadcast is free until 2016, and that includes sites with ads, so unless you plan to set up full-blown commerical operation...
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:11): it's true, if you just want to watch Youtube you'll be fine.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (03:11): Or post your own videos
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:12): I believe that technically, you need to execute a license for that. You won't have to pay royalties until 2016.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:13): it's pretty clear that until H.264 is freely usable without any license nonsense, it's not a workable solution.
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:14): plus the weird stuff they recently replied to for open source software
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:14): usable and implementable, yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:15): (and i mean Free, not $0)
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:15): and then the one where you cannot do commercial content, even if you have a license to Final Cut Pro
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:15): more and more restrictions are coming out
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:15): even if they won't go after people for such infringements, it's still a scary state
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:16): those restrictions were always there, people just didn't know or care
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (03:16): of course most still don't, as long as they can watch Youtube
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:16): it's good it is being exposed - mostly it was unknown till now
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:17): I'm still hoping Google will "do good" and provide an Ogg alternative of YouTube, too
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:17): it's a massive transcoding effort, but then they did that for mobile content and HD content, too
040342c014ffc1c11592948bd92e3721 (03:18): I don't mind large corporates continuing to use H.264 - but it shouldn't be forced upon the small guys
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (03:19): google has the computing power, I bet
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (03:34): http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/8496263.stm hum
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, sorry I didn't see your q re: vcard/n til now

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:40): Much of the "optimizations" for n (and fn and others) were design/built to bridge the impedance mismatch/gap between the way people author content (only what they have to / seems obvious), and the strict top-down a-priori requirements of various formats.

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:41): given the years of experience we've had with hCard (and n and fn uses), there's definitely been a few cases where some optimizations can be dropped, others can be improved/refined, and there's room for a few more too (again, based on experience with what authors have tried to do with hCard)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:41): I've captured much of this in hcard-brainstorming for hCard 1.0.1 (and similarly for hCalendar)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:42): essentially all such "optimizations" come down to making the vocabularies more *usable*
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:42): anyway - feel free to jump into #microformats for more on hCard/vcard/n/fn etc.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:43): btw on another topic (which was mentioned above)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:43): http://bemasc.net/wordpress/2010/02/02/no-you-cant-do-that-with-h264/
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:44): the video codec situ seems quite messy

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:50): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: k. sounds like it would be reasonable for the microdata version to just say that a blank N is generated if it's missing, then, with no special magic to generate it from FN, NICK, and ORG like hCard
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, there are probably some cases where a blank n *should* be generated from fn, nickname, org etc., even in hCard
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:53): how do you mean?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:54): that is there are some cases where hCard auto-generates a value for the 'n' property when it should probably generate an empty 'n' property
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:55): ah i see

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:55): I'm going to have to another round of tests with modern vcard consumers to understand the impact of various combinations of implying a blank 'n' vs an 'n' with a non-empty value.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:55): to have to *do* another
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:55): i have to say, one has to love how the vcard spec just says that N is required
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:56): don't get me started
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:56): without saying how you're supposed to determine its value if it's unknown
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:56): Atom does the same thing
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:56): Atom is actually much worse
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:56): a bunch of things are required, but there's no suggestion of what to do when they're unknown
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:56): so many really bad MUSTs on content authoring
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:56): and so many bad requirements for artificial precision - e.g. RFC3339
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:57): e.g. forcing you to specify :00 seconds, even if you don't know/have a value for it from the content/data/authoring
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:57): forced artificial precision = antipattern
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:57): another case of, mandating the author to provide a value for something doesn't mean that you actually get meaningful content for it
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (03:58): I'm sure you can list examples from the HTML spec for that ;)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): actually html4 doesn't do that much
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): mostly because it requires so little of anything...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): kinda the opposite problem :-P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:08): wonders why he sometimes gets "- unknown class warning" when running his script
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:08): i've tried commenting stuff out but i can't work out what is causing it
